facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 165 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 165 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated December 19, 1958 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1010 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 19, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1010 of 1956.

facts.text: Sessions Judge, Saharanpur convicted appellants for offences including under S. 302 read with s. 149, I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: confirming their conviction for several offences including one under S. 302 read with s. 149, I.P.C., by the Sessions Judge, Saharanpur.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed appellants' appeal and confirmed conviction.

anchor.surface_text: dismissing their appeal and confirming their conviction for several offences including one under S. 302 read with s. 149, I.P.C., by the Sessions Judge, Saharanpur.

facts.text: Four appellants along with three other persons alleged to have forcibly taken two carts loaded with sugarcane from field of Suraj Bhan through field of Harphool.

anchor.surface_text: These appellants, along with three other persons, were alleged to have forcibly taken two carts loaded with sugarcane from the field-of Suraj Bhan through the field of Harphool,

facts.text: Sugarcane transported from field about a furlong and a half away to public passage running by side of Harphool's field.

anchor.surface_text: in transporting the sugarcane from the field, about a furlong and a half away, to the public passage running by the side of Harphools field,

facts.text: Appellants party beat Harphool and others on Harphool protesting against conduct causing damage to his wheat and gram crop.

anchor.surface_text: and to have beaten Harphool and others on Harphools protesting against the conduct of the appellants party at the damage caused to his wheat and gram crop.

facts.text: Ram Chandar, one of the appellants, armed with a hatchet kulhari.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Chandar, one of the appellants, was armed with a hatchet  kulhari  and the others were armed with lathis.

facts.text: Others in appellants party armed with lathis.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Chandar, one of the appellants, was armed with a hatchet  kulhari  and the others were armed with lathis.

facts.text: Harphool and others struck appellants party in self-defence.

anchor.surface_text: Harphool and others who came to his help struck the appellants party also in self-defence.

facts.text: Harphool died as result of injuries received in the incident.

anchor.surface_text: Harphool died as a result of the injuries received in this incident.

facts.text: Appellants admitted taking carts through Harphool's field.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants admitted their taking the carts through Harphools field and alleged that at Harphools protest they asked to be excused,

facts.text: Appellants alleged that at Harphool's protest they asked to be excused, promised not to take carts through fields in future, pleaded to allow crossing small portion.

anchor.surface_text: promised number to take the carts through the fields in future and pleaded for the carts being allowed to cross the very small portion of the field which remained to be companyered

facts.text: Appellants alleged Harphool and companions attacked them despite appellants' meek conduct, and appellants struck in self-defence.

anchor.surface_text: The accused state that in spite of all this meek companyduct on their part, Harphool and his companypanions attacked them and that then they also struck Harphool and others in self- defence.

facts.text: Sessions Judge and High Court concurrent findings: no passage through or along boundary of Harphool's field.

anchor.surface_text: Both the learned Sessions Judge and the learned Judges of the High Court arrived at concurrent findings of fact an held that  i  there was numberpassage through or along the boundary of Harphools field

facts.text: Concurrent findings: when carts near passage and Harphool protested, appellants party began the attack.

anchor.surface_text: ii  when the carts were near the passage and Harphool protested, the appellants party began the attack and

facts.text: Concurrent findings: appellants party had no right of private defence of person but formed unlawful assembly with common object of committing criminal trespass over Harphool's field and using force to extent of causing death if necessary.

anchor.surface_text: iii  the appellants party had numberright of private defence of person but had formed an unlawful assembly with the companymon object of companymitting criminal trespass over Harphools field and using force to the extent of causing death,

facts.text: Two carts had not left Harphool's field and reached public passage; inside field when incident took place.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbersuch finding recorded by the High Court. The two carts had number left Harphools field and reached the public passage.

facts.text: Carts were near boundary of Harphool's field, several yards inside.

anchor.surface_text: They were inside the field when the incident took place. They were near the boundary of Harphools field. They must, in, the circumstances, have been several yards inside the field.

facts.text: Appellants party could have taken carts to public passage by going northwards from Suraj Bhan's field, shorter distance, trespass one field of own community Sandal Rajput.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, from the site plan, and has been so held by the Courts below, that the appellants party companyld have taken their carts to the same public passage by going numberthwards from Suraj Bhans sugarcane field.

facts.text: Appellants chose longer route through fields of several Sainis including Harphool.

anchor.surface_text: Their choosing a longer route which made them take their carts through the fields of several Sainis including Harphool, companyld number be justified.

facts.text: Harphool received seven injuries.

anchor.surface_text: Harphool did receive seven injuries one of which was an incised wound, bone deep, on the right side of the head.

facts.text: One injury: incised wound, bone deep, on right side of head.

anchor.surface_text: Harphool did receive seven injuries one of which was an incised wound, bone deep, on the right side of the head.

facts.text: Another injury: contused wound, bone deep, on left side of head.

anchor.surface_text: Another injury companysisted of a companytused wound, bone deep, on the left side of the head.

facts.text: Harphool died within twenty-four hours of receiving injuries.

anchor.surface_text: Harphool died within twenty-four hours of his receiving injuries.

facts.text: Death due to shock and hemorrhage caused by injuries of skull bone and brain from wounds on head.

anchor.surface_text: The death was due to shock and hemorrhage caused by the injuries of the skull bone and brain on account of the wounds on the head.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on March 28, 1961 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-This appeal, by special leave, is by four persons against the order of the High Court
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 19, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1010 of 1956.
1961. March 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-This appeal, by special leave, is by four persons against the order of the High Court
confirming their conviction for several offences including one under S. 302 read with s. 149, I.P.C., by the Sessions Judge, Saharanpur.

arguments.claim: Offence made out is murder under S.302 r/w S.149 IPC due to death from concerted acts in prosecution of common object

holdings.text: Criminal trespass had not therefore come to an end and therefore Harphool had the right to prevent the appellants party from continuing to commit criminal trespass for whatever short distance they had still to cover before reaching the public pathway.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal trespass had not therefore come to an end and therefore Harphool had the right to prevent the appellants party from continuing to commit criminal trespass for whatever short distance they had still to cover before reaching the public pathway.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Carts were still several yards inside Harphool's field near boundary when incident occurred; no finding that trespass ended or intention to cease indicated.

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that the three propositions of law which, as abstract propositions of law, are sound to some extent, do not arise in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the three propositions of law which, as abstract propositions of law, are sound to some extent, do not arise in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Propositions based on false supposition that trespass ended and Harphool attacked first; facts show trespass ongoing and appellants attacked first.

holdings.text: We do not agree with the contention [that High Court misdirected on inferences about common object].

anchor.surface_text: The fourth contention is really directed against the view of the High Court that the common object of the appellants party was to force their way through the fields of Harphool and to use force to the extent of causing death, if necessary, and that the death of Harphool was caused in prosecution of that common object. We do not agree with the contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inference justified by site plan showing alternative shorter route, choice of longer path through others' fields, carrying arms, nature of injuries.

holdings.text: The common object of the appellants party was to force their way through the fields of Harphool and to use force to the extent of causing death, if necessary.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstances including deliberate choice of contentious route, number of armed persons, preparation for resistance indicate violent common object.

holdings.text: The death of Harphool was caused in prosecution of that common object.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Attack occurred while still committing trespass over field; injuries inflicted in furtherance of forcing way through.

holdings.text: The offence made out on account of the death of Harphool caused by the concerted acts of the members of the appellants party has been rightly held to be the offence of murder.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Death due to severe head injuries from skull and brain damage caused by appellants' group acts in prosecution of common object under s.302 r/w s.149 IPC.

holdings.text: The appellants party had no right of private defence of person but had formed an unlawful assembly with the common object of committing criminal trespass over Harphools field and using force to the extent of causing death, if necessary.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants party had no right of private defence of person but had formed an unlawful assembly with the common object of committing criminal trespass over Harphools field and using force to the extent of causing death, if necessary, in case they were prevented from taking the carts through the fields.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of lower courts accepted; appellants initiated attack during ongoing trespass.
